subject: Art
title: What Is Color?
description: How light creates the perception of color in our eyes and brains.

hook.text: Color doesn't exist in the physical world. There's no 'red' out there â€” only electromagnetic waves of different lengths. Color is your brain's interpretation of light.

buildup.text: White light contains all wavelengths. When it hits an object, some wavelengths are absorbed and others bounce back. The wavelengths that reach your eye are interpreted as color by your brain.

discovery.text: A red apple absorbs all wavelengths except red, which it reflects. A white object reflects everything. A black object absorbs everything. Color is about what an object rejects, not what it is.

twist.text: This means color changes with light. That same red apple under blue light looks almost black â€” because there's no red light to reflect. Color is never fixed; it's always relative to the light source.

climax.text: Artists who understand this paint light, not objects. They observe how the specific light conditions affect every color in the scene.

punchline.text: Color is light. Change the light, change the color. The object is just a mirror.

quiz.question: Why does a red apple appear red?
options: It reflects red wavelengths and absorbs the rest
Red paint is on the surface
Our brain always sees apples as red
